Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 12:28PM prettypink wrote: Ladies Thanks for the information. Reading all this makes my heart drop, but I will be strong.  I will be here every step of the way...don't have much support for myself and am an only child.  I'm going home (3hours away) next week to be with my mom.  I will keep everyone posted
Posts.Title: A Diagnosis Without Surgery :( prettypink prettypink

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 09:19AM - edited May 12, 2009 09:51AM by prettypink     Yesterday my mom had her appointment with the oncologist.  She had a needle biopsy.  It took 3 tries, the first needle was too small and the second didnt collect tissue, so it took 3 tries but the doctor who was so kind and patient explained things to us. The size is 1.6 cm.  I have no idea if that is big or small.   She does believe it IS cancer, just as someone above stated those "tentacle like images" were present.  It has also grown in the last two weeks.  Now the waiting game begins.  The doctor suggested my mom make an appointment for next Friday and will then read the results.  I suppose she is that sure that it is malignant that she said her office would not phone, just be there next Friday.  I assume we will get our options at that point.  I feel like I am in shock...and this morning when I woke up for a minute I thought it was all a bad dream.  Ugh. PS.  She is very itchy at the exact site of the cancer.  Has anyone else ever experienced this?
Posts.Title: A Diagnosis Without Surgery :( prettypink prettypink

Posts.Content: prettypink wrote: My mom had surgery in 2005 to remove  lumps from her left breast.  Weeks went by, and thankfully she never had to go for treatment, as the ressults showed it to be benign.  My mom was required to go every 6 months after that for follow up mammograms.  She did for the most part, and then last september she missed her appointment.  She did not go until April of this year.  The doctors office called her back the very next day to have her come in the following day for another mammogram.  She told me it was very paainful, much more painful than the one the day before.  Monday, one week following the first mammogram, and 3 days after the second one, the doctors have told my mom it is malignant.  My heart is broken, but with all the emotions put aside, Im angry that they would give her a diagnosis like this without anything being taken out of her body and sent out for further testing....just like they did in 2005.  How can they tell her this is malignant?  Dont they need further testing...or is there a way they can tell just from the mammagram? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  Im just so confused. Thank you :) Elisa I am here with my mom, my best friend, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in April 2009. Dx 7/29/2013, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Diagnosis Without Surgery :( prettypink prettypink

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 09:58AM prettypink wrote: That is EXACTLY what I thought.  I hope we are both right.  When I asked my mom ...on what basis are they giving you this diagnosis, she told me they use it up against her baseline.  I know she is not asking all the right questions.  I think she is in shock.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 01:05PM prettypink wrote: Hi Rose Fortunately in Canada where we are from, we dont have to worry about insurance etc.  I could not imagine having to worry about finances during a time like this.  My heart goes out to anyone who does.  On the other side of the coin. Im not sure how the whole process works when health care is covered, ie) waiting lists etc.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:22AM - edited May 28, 2009 11:23AM by prettypink Fiona, Although your situation saddens me badly, I truely believe that positivity makes a change, or at least helps to. My mom and I are thinking about you.  Paryers and Hugs From Us. xoxoxo
Posts.Title: Everything is happening so fast fiona1144 lpizza726

Posts.Content: prettypink wrote:    My mom started her first of 25 rediation treatments 10 days ago.  Aside from some tender sensation, burning and sharp pains in her breast, she is extremely tired.  The specialist who sees her once a week told her everything was normal...he spent maybe 5 minutes with her yesterday.  Should she not be getting her bloodwork checked frequently during this phase?     You ladies are all so wonderful...and strong.  I simply could not come here once without telling you all how I admire every woman's strength and courage.  i love this place. :)  Elisa xoxo I am here with my mom, my best friend, who was diagnosed with breast cancer in April 2009.
